title: 109_hr6218
content: The Act may be cited as the "Bay Area Regional Water Recycling Program Projects Authorization Act of 2006". Definitions are provided in the Act. The Act defines "feasible" as a project that has completed planning and environmental studies consistent with Bureau of Reclamation procedures for projects under consideration for financial assistance. The Act defines "feasible" as a project that has completed planning and environmental studies consistent with Bureau of Reclamation procedures for projects under consideration for financial assistance. The project must demonstrate compliance with section 1604 of the Reclamation Wastewater and Groundwater Study and Facilities Act, have a financially capable non-Federal sponsor, and be technically and financially viable. The Act defines "technically and financially viable project" as a project that meets engineering, public health, and environmental standards, and has the necessary permits for implementation. SEC. 3. Bay Area Regional Water Recycling Program projects are deemed feasible and eligible for financial assistance under the Reclamation Wastewater and Groundwater Study and Facilities Act. The projects are confirmed as technically and financially viable. This section does not affect the applicability of environmental laws to the projects. SEC. 16XX. CITY OF PALO ALTO WATER REUSE PROJECT. The Secretary is authorized to participate in the design, planning, and construction of recycled water distribution systems in cooperation with the City of Palo Alto, California. The Federal share of the project cost should not exceed 25 percent. Funds for operation and maintenance will not be provided by the Secretary. $5,000,000 is authorized for appropriations, and the authority to carry out these provisions will terminate 10 years after enactment. The Secretary is authorized to participate in the design, planning, and construction of recycled water system facilities in cooperation with the City of Pittsburg, California, and the Delta Diablo Sanitation District. The Federal share of the project cost should not exceed 25 percent. Funds for operation and maintenance will not be provided. $1,300,000 is authorized for appropriations, and the authority will terminate 10 years after enactment. The Secretary is authorized to participate in the design, planning, and construction of recycled water system facilities in cooperation with the City of Antioch, California, and the Delta Diablo Sanitation District. The Federal share of the project cost should not exceed 25 percent. Funds for operation and maintenance will not be provided. $2,250,000 is authorized for appropriations, and the authority will terminate 10 years after enactment. The Secretary is authorized to participate in the design, planning, and construction of recycled water system facilities in cooperation with the City of Pacifica, California, and the North Coast County Water District. The Federal share of the project cost should not exceed 25 percent. Funds for operation and maintenance will not be provided. $1,400,000 is authorized for appropriations, and the authority will terminate 10 years after enactment. The Secretary is authorized to participate in the design, planning, and construction of recycled water system facilities in Redwood City, California. The Federal share of the project cost should not exceed 25 percent, with no funds provided for operation and maintenance. $1,100,000 is authorized for appropriations, and the authority will terminate 10 years after enactment. The Secretary is authorized to participate in the design, planning, and construction of recycled water system distribution facilities in Gilroy, California. The Federal share of the project cost should not exceed 25 percent, with no funds provided for operation and maintenance. $7,000,000 is authorized for appropriations, and the authority will terminate 10 years after enactment. Public Law 102-575 is amended to include a new item after section 16xx. The Public Law 102-575 is amended to include new projects such as the Palo Alto, Pittsburg, Antioch, Pacifica, Redwood City, and South Santa Clara County Water Reuse Projects.
